rev.diff:
Line 229: Line 229:
* Unlike Ubuntu, the philosophy of the Linux Mint project is compatible with the use of proprietary software. Linux Mint favors Open Source technology but also considers proprietary alternatives, the user experience of the desktop being the main concern with licensing coming second. For instance, most editions of Linux Mint come with Adobe's Flash plug-in installed by default.
* Unlike Ubuntu, the philosophy of the Linux Mint project is compatible with the use of proprietary software. Linux Mint favors Open Source technology but also considers proprietary alternatives, the user experience of the desktop being the main concern with licensing coming second. For instance, most editions of Linux Mint come with Adobe's Flash plug-in installed by default.
* Ubuntu and Linux Mint adopt radically different update strategies. Ubuntu recommends its users update all packages and upgrade to newer versions using an APT-based upgrade method. Resulting problems and regressions are regarded as temporary issues that can be fixed by further updates. In comparison, Linux Mint recommends not to update packages that can affect the stability of the system and recommends the use of its Backup Tool and fresh installations to upgrade computers to newer releases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.linuxmint.com/tutorial/view/2|title=Recommended way to upgrade Linux Mint|accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
* Ubuntu and Linux Mint adopt radically different update strategies. Ubuntu recommends its users update all packages and upgrade to newer versions using an APT-based upgrade method. Resulting problems and regressions are regarded as temporary issues that can be fixed by further updates. In comparison, Linux Mint recommends not to update packages that can affect the stability of the system and recommends the use of its Backup Tool and fresh installations to upgrade computers to newer releases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.linuxmint.com/tutorial/view/2|title=Recommended way to upgrade Linux Mint|accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
â
*Linux Mint is completely community driven, while Ubuntu takes input from both its community and its parent company, Canonical.
+
*Linux Mint is completely community driven, while Ubuntu takes input from both its community and its parent company, [[Canonical Ltd.|Canonical]].
